channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Get your foot in the door! UK/EU Remote Jr. Perl Developer
item.description: We know that a lack of commercial experience doesn’t always reflect skill level, know-how, or programming brilliance. You know your stuff. You’re keen to grow and learn. You know that if someone would only just give you a chance, and let you in the door, you could really shine!

item.title: Can’t find the right job? Build your own! Remote Perl role in Australia
item.description: Have you ever seen those build-a-bear kiosks in the mall? You choose the components and watch your furry friend take shape. Now imagine a kiosk where you’re building your perfect job, because that’s exactly what our latest role offers!

item.title: Cruise into this Dreamy Career. Perl role in Malta
item.description: Our client is an online financial services company, still rapidly expanding after 20 years of impressive growth. With a truly international presence, they’re well known globally in their niche. Looking for Perl developers with a strong background in Modern Perl – you should be comfortable with Moose and PSGI/Plack, and a solid grounding in using Perl’s testing tools.

item.title: A Job that Fits. 100% remote (within UK) Perl dev. Role
item.description: Our client’s mission is to empower citizens to participate in civic matters by providing the technology, tools, and data they need. From a platform that enables citizens to report roads that need fixing to democratic tools that connect citizens with politicians, this dynamic organization is changing the world for the better, one click at a time.

item.title: Wanted: Santa-level Senior Perl Developer! US remote role
item.description: The elves keep the workshop running, but some jobs call for Santa-level skills. Kris Kringles of the Perl world, if you’re an ultra-Senior Perl Developer who can work with legacy code and identify opportunities for improvement, our client has a sleigh with your name on it.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Capture STDOUT and STDERR of external program using Capture::Tiny
Revisit The Weekly Challenge - 075 (Task #1: Coins Sum)
The Weekly Challenge 144: Semiprime Ulam
item.description: Roger choose Raku solution to Semiprime task to discuss in the blog this week. Detailed analysis makes it easy to follow. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Illuminating the Ulam
item.description: Great task analysis of Ulam Sequence. Thanksfor sharing the knowledge with us.

item.title: Ulam Sequence
item.description: Mark dedicates a blog to each solution so that we can focus one solution at a time. Again this too is well documented. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Semiprimes
item.description: Mark presenting well documented Raku solution in a short and simple blog.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 144
item.description: Realy cool demo of one liner showing the use of PDL. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 144: headache!
item.description: Solution to Semiprime in Raku is really cool, showing method chaining. Just love it. Thanks.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 144: Semiprimes and Ulam Sequence
item.description: Laurent showcase the power of Raku in way that anyone can easily follow the code. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #144
item.description: James contributions week after week impressed me a lot. I learn a lot from his contribution. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC144 - Ulam Sequence
item.description: The questions section of the blog brought a big smile on my face. I didn't plan it, honestly. Raku solution is my favourite, this week.

item.title: PWC144 - Semiprime
item.description: Flavio has been kind and shared multiple approaches to solve the task. Hard to pick one, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Almost Prime and In Sequence: The Weekly Challenge #144
item.description: Great show of functional programming by Dave. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Primarily Ulam with Raku (and perl)
item.description: The solution to Semiprime task in Raku is amazingly simple. I wish I knew this before. Thanks Arne for sharing.

item.title: A Stocking Full of Numbers: Semiprimes and the Ulam Sequence
item.description: Adam presenting the power of grep in this week solution. Cool promotion of Perl power.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 140
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 144
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Semiprime" and "Ulam Sequence" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 145
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Dot Product" and "Palindromic Tree". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: AoC 2021/16 - Bitstream decoding
item.description: On with Advent of Code puzzle 16 from 2021: good old bit stream decoding

item.title: AoC 2021/15 - A* in the sea
item.description: On with Advent of Code puzzle 15 from 2021: using A*.

item.title: AoC 2021/14 - Exponential polymerization
item.description: On with Advent of Code puzzle 14 from 2021: taming exponential growth in the evolution mechanism.

item.title: AoC 2021/13 - Transparent origami
item.description: On with Advent of Code puzzle 13 from 2021: folding transparent paper, origami style.

item.title: Monthly Report - November
item.description: Late monthly report from me.

item.title: My Favorite Warnings: ambiguous
item.description: Do you want to know more about 'ambiguous' warning? Tom giving you insight on the subject.

item.title: Perl Turns 34 - A Retrospective
item.description: Nikos, sharing retrospective view on Perl. Well written article, not to be missed.

item.title: 34 at 34 for v5.34: Modern Perl features for Perl’s birthday
item.description: Mark's weekly blog to celebrate the big day with 34 cool features of Perl language.

item.title: PDL 2.063_01 released
item.description: Summary: 64-bit indexing, native complex number support, automatic pthreading using all available CPU cores, faster installation thanks to parallel-building, memory-mapped data, repository hosted on GitHub, easy to use "with" Inline.

item.title: TPRCHouston - Newsletter #1
item.description: Come to the Perl and Raku Conference in Houston! You can expect to see a lot of presentations on Perl, Raku, and supporting languages.

item.title: Supporting TPF – potential tax savings
item.description: If you consider your year-end philanthropy, wTPF highlights a few strategies that may reduce your tax liability.

item.title: #544 - Merry Christmas
item.description:
Hi there

We wish all the readers of the newsletter, Merry Christmas. I hope and wish you all enjoying quality time with your loved ones.

Belated happy birthday to my favourite language, Perl, on completing 34 years. Mark Gardner used his weekly blogging schedule to celebrate the occassion in his blog.

Do you remember which year you first picked the Perl language?

For me, I was introduced to Perl in the year 1998. So technically, I am 23 Perl years old. How about you? I am wondering if anyone other than the creator, picked the language in the first year itself. If you know the name then please do share with us. I am sure there must be handfull that I am not aware of.

Talking about birthday celebration, I would like to wish belated Happy Birthday to the mother of chief editor, Gabor Szabo. As per the record, my birthday was last Monday i.e. 20th December. Till date, I never celebrated my birthday, this year also went without celebration.

I noticed that I am getting close to my 100th edition of the newsletter. This is my 94th edition. It would be a big achievement for me, personally, to reach the number. I am looking forward to the 556th edition of the weekly newsletter as that would be my 100th edition.

Stay safe and enjoy the holiday break.
